title: Foldable <details> section in Markdown
body:
I'd like to be able to fold `
` sections in Markdown, for example ```md
Log output Some long content here...
``` A similar request was #57505 which was resolved by commit https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/commit/a118676a3b73c8972d76e5e854496fc4901dcd75 ("Allow folding of html blocks in markdown files") but I don't see this behavior in 1.33.0: (Note how the fenced code block is foldable but not the entire `
` element.)

title: Add scroll duration option or/and Add API option to set exact scroll position.
body:
Looking to emulate this behavior in VS Code: 
[Visual Studio Smooth Scrolling](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=lkytal.SmoothScroll)


For every click of the mouse wheel or key input editor scrolls with smooth acceleration for a duration . This might be windows specific. 

In user preferences there are currently 2 options:
`"editor.mouseWheelScrollSensitivity": 1`
`"editor.smoothScrolling": true`

The scrolling animation with mouse wheel as it is now is to fast, is it possible to add an additional option:
`"editor.smoothScrollingDuration" 2,
`

This will give the user control of the duration of the scrolling animation. Ideally make it possible to set the distance to travel and the duration. 

Also for extension development the API for handling scrolling is very limited. Only 1 real option:
`vscode.window.activeTextEditor.revealRange // Method only allows large motions, between 2 lines.
`

Would be great if there was a API option for changing the exact scroll position. Like this: 
`vscode.window.activeTextEditor.scrollPosition += 0.1 // Scroll down distance 0.1
`

With this one option all of my scrolling dreams can be implemented !!!

This problem also exists in the insiders version.

Steps to Reproduce:

folder like this:

```
- FolderA
 - body.js
- FolderB
```

body1.js like this:

content
```

1. Right-click FolderB and select "Search in Folders"

title: Setting to Disable Split Editor on Drag and Drop
body:
I use drag and drop a lot to move files among different columns, but never to split the editor into more columns or rows. When moving quickly, I accidentally split the editor a lot, and it slows me down and takes me out of flow. I posit that there are other users that are like this as well.

I would like a setting that disables the behavior of splitting of the panes completely. The behavior I'd like to disable is illustrated in this gif from [the docs](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/getstarted/userinterface#_grid-editor-layout):

![grid-dnd](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1935696/54869262-3b7d2080-4d96-11e9-98e3-c50b44b2bcbd.gif)

Keywords for search:

panes, panels, tabs, grid

Similar issues: #52063

title: env variables failed to load in debug for nodejs app
body:
The env variables failed to load in debug with 2 popular modules - `dotenv` and `config`. The app has no problem loading the env variables file in normal development with `nodemon index.js`. But none of the variable is loaded with `Launch index.js` in debug. Initially I thought it was problem with `config`. But after the same problem happens with `dotenv`, I am wondering if this is a bug with VS code.

Here is the VS code info:

title: Typescript issue with diagnostics and syntax highlighting
body:
Issue Type: Bug Seeing some strange highlighting and incorrect problems: ![Screen Shot 2019-03-22 at 10 15 57 AM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3672607/54841200-01bff300-4c8c-11e9-99f8-8e618998bf5e.png) I was rebasing something and had conflicts in that file with the import statements. I chose one of the options, I think keeping the incoming code, so I was expecting the diagnostics to change to issues about missing or unused imports. Instead there are now bizarro things like "Cannot find name 'constructor'" on an empty line. Here's the output from the ts channel, I couldn't easily find where things went sideways so I just included everything: [trace.txt](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/2997639/trace.txt) After restarting the TS server everything is back to normal and the only problems are on unused import statements. VS Code version: Code - Insiders 1.33.0-insider (9474154f133dbbb793ca3c128c9fcfdca39f5b26, 2019-03-22T06:15:30.293Z) OS version: Darwin x64 18.2.0

title: Invalid path causing updates to fail and shortcut to get corrupted
body:
Issue Type: Bug I have VS Code installed on the D drive (where user profiles are). It was completely failing the update each time due to "ERRO Bad arguments: Code path doesn't seem to exist." The path it provides is indicative of the underlying error though: D:\Users\FIRST.LAST\AppData\Local\Programs\Microsoft VS Code\%LOCALAPPDATA%\Programs\Microsoft VS Code\Code.exe Checking Registry, this is the path it reflects in HKEY_USERS\ID\Environment\Path, HKEY_USERS\ID\SOFTWARE\Classes\Applications\code.exe\DefaultIcon, and most other path instances and also what it updates the shortcut to on every update attempt. It's even worse in VSCodeSourceFile\shell\open\command: ""D:\Users\FIRST.LAST\AppData\Local\Programs\Microsoft VS Code\%LOCALAPPDATA%\Programs\Microsoft VS Code\Code.exe" "%1"%LOCALAPPDATA%\Programs\Microsoft VS Code\Code.exe" "%1" Looking into the actual folder, I see that it somehow created a folder based on the environment variable. Didn't realize that was even possible! D:\Users\FIRST.LAST\AppData\Local\Programs\Microsoft VS Code\%LOCALAPPDATA%\Programs\Microsoft VS Code (yes, "%LOCALAPPDATA%" is actually a subfolder there) Step to reproduce is simply to click "Update Now" when prompted. It just shows the fail dialog and breaks the shortcut. After deleting the %APPLOCALAPPDATA% folder and fixing every single VS Code path in registry it now works. Hopefully this helps track down how it happens. VS Code version: Code 1.32.3 (a3db5be9b5c6ba46bb7555ec5d60178ecc2eaae4, 2019-03-14T23:43:35.476Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.14393

title: Sort lines correct alphabetic sorting with diacritics in Romanian
body: Issue Type: Bug The correct order when it comes to Romanian diacritics would be **a, , , b, c ... i, ... s, , t, , u, v ...** [Alphabetical order - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alphabetical_order) But this is the result of **Sort Lines Ascending** on these lines: ``` Slaj Satu Mare Sibiu Suceava ``` `Slaj` should come after `Satu Mare` FWIW Sublime Text gets it worse, considering diacritics as continuing after the main latin alphabet: `Slaj` comes after `Suceava` VS Code version: Code 1.32.3 (a3db5be9b5c6ba46bb7555ec5d60178ecc2eaae4, 2019-03-14T23:43:35.476Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 6.1.7601

title: Native title bar: Recent menu not updated when switching windows
body:
- Turn on the native title bar
- open two windows, each with a different folder opened
- look at the File > Recent menu of each window

The recent menu has, by design always the own window input as the first entry.
Note that this is not the case with the native menu (works with the custom menu)

The recent menu needs to be refetched every time the window focus changes

title: Allow the command palette to accept parameters for commands
body:
Might be a dupe of https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/41692
From here: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/70876. 
Condensing from @bolinfest in that issue. There is a lot of good feedback there about commands and tasks, and I want to use that issue to address that feedback.

"I want to build an extension that lets the user type bb //foo:bar in the Command Palette and have it open a new terminal that runs buck build //foo:bar. Note this should be able to take a variable number of arguments, so bb @mode/opt //foo:bar and bb //foo:bar //foo:baz should also be possible."
"Looking at the source for VS Code itself, it seems that the internal registerQuickOpenHandler() API is basically what I want. Is this something the team would be willing to explore as a proposed API?"

title: Quick input gets wrong focus outline
Support moving between *sections* of the "themes" menu
body: Issue Type: Feature Request On macOS, search fields often have sections: More importantly, in all such sections across the operating system, there's a consistent set of keybindings for *navigating* these sections. For instance, in the above interface, as an element within the `Other` section is highlighted, hitting would leap to the first item of the `Folders` section, regardless of *which* element in `Other` was currently selected. Meanwhile, in VScode, there are several such interfaces. Notably, for me, is the "Themes" interface: Unfortunately, if my cursor is high up in the `Light themes` section, moving to the `Dark themes` section is very costly to my eyes, and not quick at all in fact, it's one of the *only* things I reliably use my mouse for, every single day! tl;dr: I'd love keybinds in the `list.*` category to jump to the first item in the (previous/next) section to the one that the cursor is currently inside. `(=` VS Code version: Code 1.32.3 (a3db5be9b5c6ba46bb7555ec5d60178ecc2eaae4, 2019-03-14T22:46:48.547Z) OS version: Darwin x64 18.2.0

title: Ability to vary completion item insertion (based on chosen commit character?)
body:
`CompletionItem` allows setting a list of commit characters that can be used to select the item. However, what you can do with that in practice is limited, since the insertion will always be the same no matter which commit character was used.

It would be very powerful if the insertion could vary depending on which commit character was selected (`insertText`, `additionalTextEdits`).

Here's an example of one of the use cases we wanted to support in the Haxe extension:

- When inserting an unimported type, we have two options: generate an import via `additionalTextEdits`, or insert the fully qualified path instead. You don't always want the same behavior here, so it would be neat if you could for instance:
    - use <kbd>Enter</kbd> to generate the import and insert the unqualified name
    - use <kbd>Tab</kbd> to insert the fully qualified name
- Right now, there's two workarounds:
    - Duplicate each completion item, so you have one for auto-importing and one for inserting fully quallified names. However, this would make for a very messy completion list, so we don't do this in the Haxe extension.
   - Have a setting that controls which behavior should be used. We _do_ have this in the Haxe extension, but as mentioned before, sometimes you want to decide which one to use "in the moment", without having to mess with settings.

There's precedent for this sort of behavior in other IDEs. For instance in IntelliJ (Java), you can use <kbd>Alt</kbd>+<kbd>Enter</kbd> to open a code action menu _on completion items_. There you can for instance choose to import a method statically:

![](https://i.imgur.com/Udt5Ofp.png)

Perhaps allowing "code actions" on completion items like that is better than basing it purely on which commit character was used, as it's much more explicit.

Thoughts?

title: [folding] custom folding text for folded ranges

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Currently when you create custom folds using a FoldingRangeProvider, there is no option to edit the text that is displayed when the text is folded. The editor just displays the first line of the fold with a three dots symbol after it. 

`#region Some region description...`

It would be helpful if it was possible for `FoldingRangeProvider` instances to return ranges with a RangeDisplayName property that would be displayed when the folding range wass collapsed. I'd suggest that the display text would replace the ... symbol and the first line would no longer be displayed as per the behaviour in Visual Studio.
